div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,459] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, APRIL 3, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST:

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Arden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Badam and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAB, ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Loverne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time fro Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer. (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.

div.head: THE THEATRE AT CAIRO.
div.p: Before writing this we happened to look at the August number of the ‘Revue d’Egypte et d’Orient,” and found on pages 352 and 353 a note on the coming season, the crowning glory in the brilliant existence of the Cercle Artistique. We will not repeat it here, but we will cite a few names mentioned—Tamagno, Caruso, Alvarez, Renaud, Boroi, Charlotte Wyns; Sammareo, Bellincioni, for opera ; for drama, Bartet, Rejane, Brand's, Guitry, pos¬sibly Sarah Bernhardt and Mounet Sully, An¬toine, Jean Coquelio, Le Bargy. Anyone can look up these names in the review in question. Whom have we had? Bellincioni for opera; for drama a week of Le Bargy, a week of the Lamberts, two performances of Coquelin,—and Moreno. And that is all. And what have we had? In opera, Asrael, a vulgar pantomime, Iris, Tannhaiiser completely travestied,Tosca, and Aida, of course; and in drama such stuff as Coeur de Moineau and La Closerie des Genets—all this done by a third-rate provincial troupe whose only two stars were far too dis couraged to show their worth to any real extent. We are told that the reign of the Cercle is over, and that a new theatre is to be built. That is good news : we shall no longer have hurried selections made anyhow (with the exception of one or two performers chosen for individual reasons), and no more pieces which no one wants to see, even well done. We know our Cercle and have suffered much at their hands : they are indeed a Cercle en-¬closing in an unbroken ring all choice, and im-¬pervious to all public opinion, getting up exhibitions of pictures in which only a few bad French paintings are shown, to represent an International Fine Arts Exhibition. And we know our theatre at Cairo,—small, chilly, badly ventilated, with its interminable entr’-actes, and its crowd of apathetic abonnes, who annex every stall in the place long before the season begins, and who, daring the season, drown all the performance by ceaseless coughs, whispers, rustling, and shifting of feet.

They are not a large nor an important notion of Cairo : they have bought their seats as they might buy a frockcoat: a certain cachet, and veil of taste, gentility, and artistic propensities, enhanced by the chance of wearing evening dress, is obtained for the money. The few enlightened people who have boxes are an entire minority. Now that very minority—a few French and Italian and Syrian theatregoers, and very occasionally two or three of the English community, represents the real Cairo public for which the theatre should be open, that public who would go to good places in a good theatre, for good performances, but who will not go near the Khedivial Opera House except once in a way to a box. And that public is highly educated, musical, possessing more than one language, knowing books and plays and pictures, a public most of whom have heard the great plays and operas at Paris, London, and elsewhere : why then exclude them 1 We want a large theatre properly built, with not only stalls but some convenient circle where the abounds might be housed—they might have the seats there—and welcome. The stalls and boxes, except a very few, should be open to everyone: in a word it should be an attraction for this very resident public and for the Visitors. A ; good manager who knows that his “house” depends on his efforts would soon see that good pre- formances were given, and that people were not played with, and laughed at, treated with that cynical and financial contempt which we have had hitherto; the artistes would respond to a good audience instead of showing, as did Coquelin, and to a slight degree the Le Bargy troupe, that they are playing to the ignorant. The Cairo audience has been called cold : of course it is, this abound section which takes up so much place in the Cairo theatre, the Con¬tinental Bar, and such places. and so little if any—in the life and thought of European Cairo.

The state of affairs and the remedy is obvious to anyone who frequents the theatre. Everyone has paid, and so no one cares : the very few who do are not listened to. The whole at¬mosphere real as metaphorical of the theatre is now chilly, now stifling—apathy smiled on by cynicism. Of course we can net always hope for the great names we have quoted, but we can always have some: and the troupe in general can be better selected, as also some conductor whose sole interests are not brass and crashing effects out of place,—as also a chorus with some sort of voice and volume, not to mention time. At present the average night is like, let us say, an "off-night” at Malta, if as good : and in the Valetta Theatre you pay eighteenpence , or at most two or three shillings, for a stall. Let us hope that the change is really going to take place that we are going to have what we want, and that-the 1905-6 season is the last inglorious flicker of what can we call it but pre artistic Cairo. Let the financiers return to their stocks and shares, and the abounds to their bars, and leave the management open for those who will devote themselves to pleasing Cairo, and the theatre to those who are only too ready to be pleased, who can appreciate and applaud whatever is really worthy of their attention.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Tantah Agricultural Show.
The Khedivial Agricultural Society has decided to organize an agricultural show at Tantah to take place next November.
British Soldier Killed.
A British soldier, in a state of inebriety, was run over and killed by a tramcar at Abbassieh while attempting to mount the car as it was proceeding.
Jewish Hospital.
A performance will be given on Wednesday evening at the Zizinia Theatre for the benefit of the Jewish Hospital at Alexandria when Manon will be performed.
Fire on Board,
The damage by the fire of the 30th ult. to the cargo of the Cunard S S. Veria was not so heavy as was at first anticipated, and the vessel sails to day for Liverpool direct.
Union Artistique Francaise.

The performance given by the above society on Sunday night was a great success, a very full “house” being present. Among the audience we noted Consul-General and Mme Girard, M. Escoffier, M. Poilay, M. Wel'hoff, etc,
Egyptian Improvements Corporation.

The contract of the sale of the Hekskian property in Soliman Pacha-street, Cairo, to the Egyptian Improvements Corporation has been completed. It was purchased for L E 51 955 by the Corporation on behalf of a group of capitalists.
The Cafe Zarani.

Yesterday Me-srs. Thos. Cook & Son took possession of this well known Alexandria cafe. Within the next two months many alterations will be made in the existing building so as to render it a convenient site for the banking, tourist, and engineering branches of the firm of Cook. They will be completed in two months’ time.
Austro-Hungarian Ball.

Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield has kindly put the landing-stage at the Port-Office at the disposal of guests going onboard the Austro-Hungarian ships on the occasion of the ball to be given on the 5th inst. Carriages should drive right up to the covered steam launches lying at the quay off the Port-Office which will be lighted by search-lights.
An Unlucky House.

Three years ago Egypt was shocked by an atrocious double murder at Zagazig when two European ladies, Mmes Benetti and Galli, were assassinated by Arabs. The population christ¬ened the house as ‘ The Abode of Misfortune” and on Sunday night the house fulfilled the destiny of this appellation by completely col¬lapsing. No one was killed, fortunately. It was inhabited by a Greek doctor.
The Mixed Courts.

As a result of the adoption of English as a judicial language a number of British lawyers have become members of the Egyptian Bar. There will be, consequently, four languages spoken in the Courts. The Berlitz Schools of Language: Cairo, Sharia Kamel, and Alex-andria, 12, Rue Rosette, will then render the greatest services to all those magistrates, lawyers, or employes who desire to become familiar with any of these languages. [Advt.]
Egyptian Institute.

A meeting of the Egyptian Institute will be held on Monday next at 6 p.m., when Prof. Elliot Smith will read a paper "On the mea¬sures taken to mould the form of the body in Mummies of the XXI Dynasty, with some remarks on the association of the Four Genii of Amenths with the viscera (with lantern views); Aly Bey Bahgat will speak on "Le Plu- mier du grand philosophe arabe Al Ghizali,” and Mr. N. Giorgiadis on • '.La Pharmacie en Egypte.”
Sacred Concert.

On Thursday in Holy Week, 9th inst., at 5.30, a performance of Stainer’s ‘‘Crucifixion’’ will be given in All Saints’ Church, Cairo, in aid of church funds, particularly of the organ fund. The fact that the present organ cannot lest much longer must be evident to any one with knowledge of such matters. No charge will be made for admission to the church, but it is hoped that every one will remember that they should contribute not less than the usual ticket price of such a concert if held in an ordi¬nary room,
Foundlings’ Ball.

To-night, at the New Khedivial Hotel, a ball will be given in aid of the Foundlings’ Home. Suppers will be served after the ball at P.T. 30 per head. It is advisable to retain tables beforehand. Following is the menu :
Consomme Madrileno
Filets do solo a la Russe
Cotolettcs d’Agneau, Chauron
Viande froide assortio
Salade Parisienne
Macedoine de fruits, frappee
Dessert.
New Way of Paying Old Debts.

A Keneh merchant, who for some time had been addicted to hasheesh, became possessed of the most morbid ideas, and on being pressed by some of his creditors to pay some old debts, whereas he had not the wherewithal, deter¬mined to commit suicide. This he did (our Keneh Correspondent says) the other morning after breakfasting as usual and going out to his shop. He returned an hour later and fixed a rope to the roof of his room. After making a noose round his neck be kicked away the chair on which he stood and so put an end to his life. His body was afterwards discovered hanging by his wife and family.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: A SUCCESSFUL COMPANY.
NEXT YEAR’S PROSPECTS.

The first annual report of the above com¬pany, which appeared in our columns yesterday, will have been pleasant reading to the many shareholders of this very successful enterprise. Seldom in any country, and hardly ever in Egypt, has a board of directors been enabled to show such splendid results for the first year of a company’s existence. This is all the more remarkable when one considers that, the working period has only been for about nine months, and that the company has only had full use of the total issued capital during six months.

The dividend on the ordinary shares is at the rate of 20% per annum, free of income tax, or l/ in the £ and the large sum of £102,090. 12.10 has been placed to reserve. Besides this, the whole of the preliminary expenses, amounting to £23,98.14.8, are written off, and a balance profit of £9,189 11.7 is carried forward into the newyear. Doubtless the Chairman at the first annual meeting, which will be held in London on the 11th inst., will give some further information of an interesting nature to the shareholders, but the above figures already speak for themselves with much force, notwithstanding what he may yet have to say

It is known that the company own large and valuable agricultural estates, besides several building lands, bought at considerably below present values, and these, coupled with the conservative policy of placing the above sum of £102.090. 2.10 to the reserve fund, entitle the Egyptian Estates to rank with the premier companies in this country.

In most cases the success of a company is the work of one individual and the Egyptian Estates, Limited, is no exception to the role. Mr. Montagu Summers, the managing director and founder of the company, has displayed remarkable ability in the conduct of the com-pany’s affairs, as the balance-sheet proves, and the ungrudging way in which he has worked for the benefit of the general body of shareholders has presented to us an object- lesson on the conduct of public companies in this country. His efforts have at the same time been well backed up by the very able members of the advisory board in Egypt.

Although the first year has been so successful, we are informed that there is every sign that the coming year will be even more so. The company begins its new year free of all preliminary expenses, which is quite exceptional, and with a profit of £9 189.11.7 in hand. Considerable profits on building lands, of which only a part were taken into last year's accounts, are due in the coming 12 months, and the agricultural estates will also have a full twelve months’ working, which will materially enhance the profits in the next balance sheet.

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
div.p: THE AKABA AFFAIR.
QUESTION IN THE HOUSE
(Gazette's Special Service)
LONDON. Tuesday.

Mr. Walter Runciman, replying to a ques¬tion in the House of Commons, said that there was no reason to suppose that the Akaba question would not be settled. Negotiations are proceeding in the usual way.
AMERICAN COAL STRIKE
(Gazette’s Special Service)
LONDON, Tuesday.
New York advices to day state that the masters have plenty of coal stored and will not surrender. The men’s strike funds are esti¬mated to amount to a million sterling.

div.head: THE PRINCE & THE COUNCILORS
div.p: We hear that H.R.H. the Prince of Wales greatly pleased the members of the Legisla-tive Council who had the honour of being presented to him on Friday last, by his speech of welcome, in which he expressed his great satisfaction at meeting the representatives of the nation, and by his cordial references to the agricultural progress of the country by his commendation of the educational activity of the notables of Egypt, and his good wishes for the future of Egypt and its people.

H.E. Abdel Hamid Pacha Saddik thanked the Prince in his name and that of the Council and remarked that the agricultural progress of the country was due not only to the irrigation works that had enriched it but to the justice which the land enjoyed under the auspices of H.H. the Khedive. After referring to the interest taken by the notables in education, he expressed his pleasure and that of his colleagues at greeting the son of H.M. King Edward VII,. Who, when Prince of Wales, had also paid Egypt the compliment of a visit.

div.head: PRINCELY ENGAGEMENTS.
div.p: A marriage has been arranged between Prince Kamel Pacha Fadel and Fatimeb Hanem Effendi, daughter of Abdulla Pacha, who is of English origin, and the widow of the late Menshawi Pacha. The “Akd’ was signed by Sheikh Selim El Bishri. Chancellor of Al Azhar University The lady has been given the title of Princess. The ceremony was attended by a large number of Turkish and Egyptian notables. Prince Aziz Pacha Hassan and Prince Haider Pacha were among those present. ‘

At the same time the Chancellor of Al Azhar signed the "Akd” of marriage between O man Bey Ameen, a notable of Cairo, and Princess Amineh Hanem Effendi, daughter of Prince Kamel Pacha Fudel; but the Princess will remain Princess, and not take the title of her husband, as Princess Nazli did.

div.head: WEATHER IN UPPER EGYPT.
div.p: A telegram from Luxor states that the weather in Upper Egypt has become quite cool again. Yesterday’s maximum temperature under the colonnade of the Luxor Hotel was 81 deg. Fahrenheit; to-day at 9 a.m. it was 66 deg.

div.head: KHARTOUM LAND SETTLEMENT
div.p: The result of the land settlement in the Khartoum province will be made public this month. The announcement will, believes the "Sudan Times,” disappoint everybody and shatter the hopes of many. Government has guarded against that bete noire, speculation, in the most effective manner, some say tot he extent of sacrificing large interests.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CAPITAL WANTED.
div.p: It is stated that Mr. Jean Pezmazoglonf general manager of the Bank of Athens, is to pay a visit shortly to Egypt in order to find capital for a new company, whose object is the development of the wine industry in Greece.

div.head: A NEW BANK.
div.p: The Commercial Bank of Italy intends to found branches at Cairo, Alexandria, and Constantinople, and its statutes are to be mo¬dified with a view to permitting these inno¬vations.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: PRINCE AT SAKKARAH.
THE PROGRESS OF ROYALTY.
Bedreshein, Sunday.

The usually somnolent village of Bedreshein, which is the station for Sakkara (refer to Baedaecker), is in a great state of excitement over the approaching visit of the Royal tra-vellers, who are timed to arrive there at ten o’clock tomorrow, Inshallah! Inter alia the venerable Sheikh of Bedreshein, Mohamed Dodo, has prepared according to his humble estimation a worthy reception, consisting of Bedouin flags and banners draped across the hamlet's most noble thoroughfare. Mohamed is the proud owner of sixty donkeys and donkey-boys, and these have also been decked out for the auspicious occasion.

With all due acknowledgments for the kindly intention, his Royal Highness will be wise in preferring the more comfortable locomotion of the Khedive’s brougham, which his Highness has graciously placed at the disposal of his Royal guests. In this vehicle, by the bye, the distinguished travellers will drive to the Tombs of Sakkara. The progress of Princes acts as a healthy stimulus to national life. Potemkin built villages along the route followed by Catherine of Russia ; Kaiser William’s visit extended very considerably the system of com- munications of the Ottoman metropolis ; H.I.M. the Sultan proceeds once a year to Stamboul by way of a sanded road. So, too, at Sakkara. a carriageable route, formed of Nilotic mud, crosses the smiling grass lands between the palm-groves of Bedreshein and the edge of the Lybian wilderness.

In the scant shade of this magnificent grove lie the rains of the Temple of Phta, the Sun-God, a picturesque grouping of columns and Egyptian capitols, scattered around a silent pool. Beyond this, and similarly protected from the tense rays of the real god of day, is the statue of Rameses II, on whom be peace. It is of gigantic proportions but withal has nothing of awful majesty about it—indeed the sculptor has given to the Royal lips an expression of beautiful benevolence. When the writer arrived, he found the custodians busily engaged in washing his Egyptian greatness with a plentiful supply of soap and water !

The desert route is lined with stones, and is regularly patrolled by Egyptian police. The Matson Marietta has also been fitted out for the nonce and in one of the rooms looking out on to the desert a table has been daintily pre¬pared on which two glasses and as many napkins stand conspicuous. This, however, was a sacri¬-legious peep through a crack in the partition. Also we may note that a wag has added to the Osirian inscriptions on the Tomb of Mira the more popular one of “God bless the Prince of Wales.” XENOS.

The Prince and Princess of Wales paid a visit to Sakkarah yesterday. T.R.H. left Abdeen Palace at 8.25 a.m. for Cairo station, whence they proceeded at 8.40 by special train to Bedreshein, arriving there at 9.10 a.m. The journey to Sakkarah was accomplished by 11 a.m. and after visiting the Temple and the Serapeum, the Royal party lambed at Mariette’s House. Leaving Sakkarah about 8 p.m. their Royal Highnesses reached Cairo at 6 o’clock, having travelled from Bedreshein on board H.H. the Khedive's yacht Tehel el Bahrein.
BANQUET AT ABDEEN PALACE.

At Saturday’s dinner at Abdeen Palace, cover were laid for SH. Prince Fuad, Lord and Lady Cromer and the members of the Corps Diplomatique, the Ministers, Advisers, heads of Departments, and Under Secretaries of State were present, with numerous members of H.H the Khedive’s civil and military household.
NATIVE APPRECIATION
"Al Zaher” says : -

The Kings of England have a very good custom of sending their Heirs Apparent to visit the colonies, which they are one day de-tined to role over. These visits are not only useful for the Government hot for the Princes themselves. The Prince and Princess of Wales are now on a visit to Egypt, which welcomes them and receives them with great joy and with as much cordiality as was our own Khedive received at Windsor Castle. Now on this matter we have a word to say to some native cavillers, whose gossiping must cease. Some people appear to think that this official visit of the Prince and Princess of Wales to Egypt is equivalent to an acknowledgment that in the opinion of England this country is a British colony. They argue that the pro¬gramme of the arrangements made for the visit of the Prince aid Princess show that the official festivities in Egypt will be quite as elaborate as they were in India. They declare that we Egyptians are, just as though we were Skilluks from the Sudan, to be decked up to please the royal guests, for a joust with old rifles and holding Arab sports of an anti¬quated fashion. Where are Amrhibn-el-Aassi and his heroes, where i- Khalid ih el-Wel eed and Tarik ibn Zyad ? What would there say when they saw how the world was now-a days and how poor a figure their descendants now out! To these and all such cavillings we make the following reply :—

The visit of our Royal guests is of great use to Egypt. They will see with their own eyes how prosperous and peaceable is the state of our land and thus they may take measures on their return home to induce the high Govern¬ment authorities to bestow on Egypt the in¬dependence which she deserves.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: LARGEST SHIP THROUGH CANAL.
A PILOT’S EXPLOITS.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Monday.

The leviathan S.S. Quiloa, the second of four new British India steamers of the same type, recently built for their coast service, arrived here on Friday. One of our brilliant examples of seamanship, a Greek pilot, board-ed her at once and proceeded, much to the amusement of the numerous onlookers, to run over two buoys, one of which was 17 feet high and was surmounted by a gas lamp and gallery. After some ‘ little incidents,” which he informed the captain were "No-ding Sare” (Anglice "Nothing sir”) he sent two enor¬-mous lines to a mooring buoy on the wrong side of the harbour and went ahead in such a manner that these had to be left OD the buoy and recovered afterwards. The process of bringing the ship in, etc., occupied four and a half hours,— a record performance, the ship being eventually fast at half-past two p.m.

The Quiloa is a turret ship of the latest type, carrying 12,500 tons cargo and displacing 16,700 tons. She has a length of 478 feet and a huge beam of 50 feet, which measurements make her quite the largest ship to go through the Canal. She steams 11 knots and is intended for service between Bombay and Calcutta. She went through the Canal in 29 hours, of which three were taken up in being tied up to permit the passage of other ships.
The S.S. Chatham.

Two days ago a telegram arrived, "Passage round Chatham dear,” and ships passed the spot with ease. To-day, evidently, other pieces of broken hall have been discovered, for the passage has been stopped for a few hours until such time as the channel can be re- buoyed, as was the case form«rly. No actual reliable information can be gathered as to the state of things at Kil 10, but it is antici¬pated that the Canal will be absolutely clear of all signs of wreckage of this somewhat interesting ship by the end of April. Consi¬derable dredging has to be done, but the greater part of the mass of twisted and broken ironwork has been removed When down at the spot a fur days ago I saw on the eastern bank no less a quantity of broken plates and frame* than 8'H) tons. This, coupled with the 700 tens odd now in Port Said, should pretty nearly represent the whole of the hall.
Dinner to the Governor.

Last Saturday the elite of Port Said gave a farewell banquet to H.E. the Governor at the Eastern Exchange. Over 70 sat down to dinner, including all the Consuls. After dinner speeches were made by the British and Greek Consuls, the Slub Governor, and others. His Excellency, in replying, said that it grieved him very much to leave all his friends here, and added that he would remember their friendship as long as he lived. During dinner a band played.
THE HOLY CARPET.
(PROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Suez Monday.
Early this morning a salute of guns announ-ced the arrival of the Holy Carpet by the S.S. Rehmanieh from Tor.

In the afternoon the usual procession through the principal streets of the town took place, the route being decorated with flags. The escort of the Mahmal in-cluded Mounted Police, Infantry, and Mountain Artillery.
The Mahmal leaves by special train for Cairo to-night.

The Holy Carpet and its escort left Tor for Suez on Sunday. The festival of the return of the Holy Carpet will take place in Cairo pro¬bably on Saturday next. H. H. the Khedive will preside at the ceremony and the Ministries and State Departments will be closed.
ARCHDEACONRY OF THE CHURCH OF ENGLAND IN SYRIA.

The Venerable Archdeacon Frere has accept¬ed the offer of preferment in England in the diocese of Gloucester, and will vacate the archdeaconry and the chaplaincy of Beyront early in the summer. The Bishop in Jerusalem has offered the archdeaconry and also the chaplaincy of Beyront to the Rev. Canon Strange, who has held the chaplaincy at Port Said since 1882. Canon Strange has been a most diligent and earnest chaplain in this difficult post. He built the station church. He was nominated by the Bishop to an honorary canonry in St. George’- Church in 1901.
Canon Strange will take time to consider his acceptance of the offer now made to him. There can be no doubt of his suitableness for it.
FLOREAT DAMANHOUR.

The inhabitants of Damanhour have been eager for the Government to endow their town with a municipal regime of a similar character to those at Mansourah and Medinet el-Fayoum, and it has been therefore decided to establish a mixed local Commission of eleven members in that town. The members will be the Moudir of the Behera province (chairman), the inspector of the Western Towns and State Buildings or his delegate, and the sanitary inspector of the province or his substitute. These persons will be members in right of their position. The remainder wall consist of four European and (oar native members chosen by the electorate.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince de Putbus, who has been passing the season in Cairo, gave a luncheon party at the Continental Hotel on Saturday. His guests were Jonkheer Van der Does de Villebois, Diplomatic Agent for the Netherlands, Mme and Miles de Villebois, Baron and Baroness de Trauttenberg, M. and Mme de Hoeltzke, Count and Countess Radolin, Mme de Leheneff, Baron de Bassus, General de Wartensleben, Count Hahn, Count de Wedel, and Countess Lotum, who is the daughter of Prince de Putbus.

H.H. the Khedive has conferred the rank of Grand Officer (2nd class) of the Medjidieh on Sir Chas. Scotter, and of Officer (4th class) of the Osmanieh on Mr. R. H. du Boulay, former-¬ly of the defunct Salt Administration.
Among the passengers who left for Europe by the Austrian boat on Saturday were Count Zichy, Baron von Winkler, Count Teleki, Count Schweipitz, Mr. Leigh Hunt, Countess Grote, Capt. Browne, etc.
Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Guiness are leaving Ireland to join their yacht at Alexandria. They will probably visit Cairo and Athens, and will be away about two months.
Mohamed Bey Tewfik. Sub-Moudir of Behera, will shortly be permitted by the Ministry of the Interior to retire on pension.
Mr. A J. Michaelides, who, we are glad to hear, has quite recovered from his recent accident on the Helouan race-course, has come down to his Sidi Gaber residence for the summer season.

We regret to learn that Mr. Klingler. The courteous and popular manager of the Con¬tinental Hotel, has been laid up for the past fortnight at the Deaconesses’ Hospital with an attack of fever. Until his recovery the management is under the direction of Mr. E. Nagel.
THE CENSUS.

According to a native contemporary the Government will take a census of Egypt’s population next year. The control of this work is be entrusted to an Anglo Indian official, who will receive a salary of LE. 3,000 per annum.
DAMIETTA.

Owing to the discontent at Damietta with the scheme of the Government to suppress that town’s organisation as a Gonvernorat and to transform it into a Mirkaz united with Farascour, the Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior has promised to reconsider the project.
A. S. C.
MUNICIPAL CUP.

The following are the conditions of this race, to take place on the 2nd day of the 1st Sum¬mer Meeting; A cup value P.T. 5 000, together with P T 5 000 presented by the Alexandria Municipality and P.T. 5,000 added money, viz : P T. 7 000 to winner, P.T. 2,000 to 2nd horse, and P.T 1.000 to 3rd horse. Handicap for Arabs Distance twice round the course. Entrance P.T. 500.
Entries will close at 4 p.m. on Friday, 27th April, 1906.
The 5th race on the 2nd day of the 1st Sum- mer Meeting. Rimleh Scurry, will not take place as advertised, but the Municipal Cup will be substituted for it
W. 0. WILKINSON,
Secretary.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Moss liner Tabor arrived this morning from Glasgow via Gibraltar and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Ellerman S. S. Algerian sailed from Liverpool last Saturday for Lisbon, Gibraltar, Malta, and Alexandria.
The S. S. City of Cambridge left Malta last night and is due here with passengers and mails on Friday next.
The S.S. Tuscan Prince has left Manchester and is due here on or about the 17th inst.
The S. S. Scottish Prince has left London and is due here on or about the 19th inst. with general cargo from Antwerp and London.
The S.S. Carib Prince, from Alexandria, arrived at Manchester on Thursday last.
The S.S. Spartan Prince, from Antwerp and London, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Monday, and is due at Alex¬-andria on Thursday evening.

div.head: TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS.
div.p: ANGLO-RUSSIAN UNDERSTANDING
WILL IT COME ABOUT?
LONDON, April 2.

The "Times’’ says that not a few Englishmen hope that the Algeciras Conference will farther stimulate the policy of supplementing the Franco-Russian Alliance and the Anglo-French Entente by the natural complement, namely, a cordial Anglo-Russian understanding. (R.)
NEW RUSSIAN LOAN.
TO BE ISSUED AFTER EASTER.
LONDON, April 2.
The "Times” says that a Russian loan of £50,000,000 is expected to be issued after Easter. It is stated in Paris that France will take £10.000,000. (Reuter)
THE KING’S CRUISE
H.M. TO LEAVE BIARRITZ TO-DAY.
LONDON, April 2.
The Queen has gone to Marseilles to join the King on board the Royal yacht. Sir Charles Hardinge will accompany the King, who leaves Biarritz to-morrow. (Reuter)
BIARRITZ April.2.
King Edward has left for Marseilles, heir greatly cheered. (Havoss)
THE AMERICA CUP.
SIR T. LIPTON’S NEW CHALLENGER.
LONDON, April 2.
Sir T. Lipton has commissioned Messrs. Mylne of Glasgow to design a new challenger for the America Cup. {Renter)
DISORDERS IN SEISTAN.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 2. The Russian Consul at Seistan telegraphs that quarantine cannot be enforced in conse- quence of disorders. Plague is increasing and spreading northward. (Reuter)
THE DOUMA ELECTIONS.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 2.
The elections to the Douma are proceeding in a normal manner. (Hanoi)
DURBAN EXECUTIONS.
DURBAN, April 2.
The natives, condemned to be shot, were executed this morning. (Reuter)
CRICKET.
LONDON, April 2.
M.C.C. won the fourth Test Match by 4 wickets, and the South Africans the fifth Test Match by an innings and sixteen runs. (B.)

div.head: Calendar of Coming Events

row.cell: Khedivial Hotel. Foundlings' Home Annual Fete.
Zizinia Theatre. Italian Opera Com-pany in Asrael. 9.
A.S.C. grounds. Shem el Nessim Skye Meeting.
Ghezireh Palace Hotel Band Per-formance. 4 p.m.
Grand Continental Hotel. Concert by Military Band. 4.
Zoological Gardens. Afternoon Con-cert by the Ghizeh Boys' Band.
National Hotel. Military Concert on terrace by Band of 2nd Batt. R. Inniskilling Fusiliers. 4-6.
Shepheard's Terrace. Military Con-Savoy Hotel. Small Dance. 10.
Zoological Gardens. E.A. Infantry Band.. Afternoon. . . .
British Recreation Club. Annual general meeting. 6.

div.p: Last week. Military School Sports.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON EXPORTS
div.p: TO LANCASHIRE.

A correspondent writes to the "Manchester Guardian” pointing out the since that 1st September last the quantity of Egyptian cotton which has either arrived at or is on the way I the port of Manchester amounts to 170,12 bales, whereas for the corresponding period la: season it was only 126,307 bales—a gain of 43,813 bales. Exports from Egypt to Liverpool during this period amounted to 177,156 bale which is a gain in comparison with last season of 9,986 bales. Manchester ten years ago on! received 20 per cent. of the exportations of Egyptian cotton to Great Britain.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The Egyptian weather is undoubtedly gaining an evil reputation. The changes which have occurred of late have been as erratic as one is accustomed to expect in the "old country". Certainly we have had unusual weather-sudden changes from hot to cold, from dry to wet. A gale blew last night and con-tinues til this morning, when rain fell and threatended to con-tinue throughout the day. The glass shows a tendency to rise.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 8 a.m. yesterday

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.
